Award.AwardTitle: Developoment Of A New Subsistence Adaptation In Middle America

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Gerardo Gutiérrez, of the University of Colorado-Boulder, in collaboration with an interdisciplinary team of US and Mexican scholars, will investigate the economic and ideological changes that human groups underwent during their transition from highly mobile hunter and gatherers to settled agriculturalists in permanent villages, between 3500 to 600 BC in southern Mexico. This is a key moment in the human history of the Americas because many of the plants that comprise our present food production economy (such as maize, or corn) were domesticated during this period. Because ancient foods do not preserve well, this cultural transition is not effectively understood for the North American continent. Why did some forager groups experiment with early cultigens and begin to rely on cultivated plants? How were economic changes reflected in or encouraged by their beliefs and social structures? Archaeological exploration in a cave in southern Mexico should provide a better understanding of the adoption of maize as the primary cereal crop of the New World (and today, a significant crop in many parts of the Old World). Much of the cave is covered with mural paintings from this transitional period (Late Archaic and Olmec style) probably painted between 3500-600 BC. These paintings provide a remarkable opportunity for insight into what people perceived about the transition from simple societies in which everyone was more or less equal to much larger societies in which a few people held sway over many.

Dr. Gutiérrez and his team will explore a dry cave that offers evidence of human occupation during the transition from a foraging to an agricultural economy. Sediments in this cave will be analyzed to uncover plant remains which are known to preserve well in dry caves and evaluate their importance in the changing diet of the people who inhabited the area. The researchers will also obtain scientific dates for the mural art and determine the chemical composition of the ancient paints to assess the sources of their pigments, the application of colors, and the styles represented. When fully studied, these murals will offer an unusual window into the ideologies and social beliefs of humans making the transition to agriculture. This research will be conducted in the Balsas River Basin of southern Mexico, the region of the Western Hemisphere with the earliest evidence of corn domestication. A team of archaeologists, paleobotanists, geomorphologists, art historians and restorers will undertake surface survey, mapping with unmanned aerial vehicles, x-ray fluorescence analysis, excavation, obsidian sourcing, and the study of micro- and macro-botanical remains. These studies will generate new quantitative and comparative data to investigate changes in landscapes, food production, resource consumption and the formation of exchange networks to evaluate rigorously the emergence of agriculture and social complexity in the New World. This research will provide opportunities for US and Mexican students to be trained in scientific methods, while promoting cooperation and understanding between academic communities of Mexico and the US.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes of the Project

The project Development of a New Subsistence Adaptation in Middle America was an interdisciplinary archaeological project that investigated the economic, cultural, and ideological changes in the transition between Archaic and Formative periods (8000-600 BC). During this time some Mesoamerican groups developed agriculture, permanent settlements, and took steps toward increased social complexity. This project has begun to fill a critical gap in Eastern Guerrero’s prehistory by studying a number of rock shelters with evidence of both pre-Olmec and Olmec use. The earliest remains came from the Cacalotepexi 1 rockshelter in the municipality of Tlapa, which presented an intriguing bench feature at the back of the cave; it had been created by mixing calcium carbonate together with multicolored chert flakes, charcoal, and bones of small animals; this feature is coeval in time with the Clovis culture of Texas. The second case was the rock shelter of Cauadzidziqui in the municipality of Copanatoyac offering the only known mural-painting palimpsest that depicts both pre-Olmec and Olmec style themes. A third rock shelter identified and studied by this project was the cave of Los Gobernadores de Techan with monolithic sculptures of were jaguars along with two altar-thrones carved out of the rock walls.

 

Knowledge of the properties and use of dehydrated calcium carbonate during the Paleo-Indian period is notable, as it would become a key component in the nixtamalization process of domesticated Zea mays (corn) preparation. Perhaps nixtamalization was first practiced on teosinte grains prior to the development of corn at the beginning of the Archaic period. New technology occurring during the key transition period comes from material analysis of the pre-Olmec and Olmec mural paintings of Cauadzidziqui and other rock art of Eastern Guerrero, which demonstrates a change from mineral pigment colors during the Archaic period to the use a lake colors in the Olmec period. A lake color is a complex material that combines organic molecules, extracted from dying plants, fixed with mineral mordants. Hence, the Olmec style mural of Cauadzidziqui presents the first use of a synthetic color and marks a technological revolution in Mesoamerican chemistry during the transition from hunter-gather groups to sedentary communities. The monumental carved sculptures of Techan highlights that being Olmec in Guerrero is not restricted to mural paintings or figurines but includes stone media as well. It may also indicate that there were many more sites participating in the larger prestige economy among emerging leaders of the Formative period of Mesoamerica.

 

The impacts of this project to the discipline are manifold:

1) Possible identification of human occupation in the Balsas River basin that was coeval with Clovis culture in Texas.

2) The identification of probable manipulation of calcium carbonate to create archaeological features that bundled together animal bones, charcoal, and distinctively colored flints—elements that likely carried deep ritual significance in Mesoamerica.

3) The demonstration of an understanding of the properties of dehydrated calcium carbonate during the Paleo-Indian period, the key component in the nixtamalization process used in preparing Zea mays (corn); this implies an early development of this process that may have been first practiced on teosinte grains, the predecessor to domesticated corn.

4) The presence of the technologies to create color for mural painting in caves, with a transition from mineral colors during the Archaic period to a palette using lake colors for the first time, which are synthetic colors combining organic molecules of color fixed with clays or metallic salts.

5) The manifestation of Olmec iconography both in mural paintings and in monumental carved rock marked a change to an economy based on agriculture, permanent settlements, and the emergence of a ranked society with leaders who manipulated access to extrinsic ideology and resources.

 

All the above elements are ground-breaking paths to further our understanding of the transition from hunter-gatherer groups to agricultural communities.
